Since no mention of pain or vision issues, classify as mild. - Urgency level: Most subconjunctival hemorrhages are benign and self-limited; therefore, routine care is sufficient unless signs of deeper injury are present, so I consider urgency as routine. - Differential considerations still requiring monitoring: Watch for signs of globe rupture, hyphema, or orbital fracture if trauma is significant.  STEP 2 - EVIDENCE-BASED TREATMENT SELECTION: - First-line treatment: Reassurance and observation, as subconjunctival hemorrhages usually resolve spontaneously within 1-2 weeks. - Supporting evidence: Literature indicates no specific medical therapy accelerates resolution, and interventions like artificial tears help with comfort. - Patient-specific considerations: The patient has baseline health and no current ocular pathology, so conservative management is appropriate. - Contraindications or cautions: Avoid topical steroids or anticoagulants unless indicated; monitor for signs of progression or complications.  STEP 3 - PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Primary medication choice: Artificial tears (e.g., preservative-free lubricating drops) applied as needed for ocular comfort. - Rationale: Enhances comfort, reduces irritation associated with tearing. - Expected timeline for improvement: Symptoms generally resolve within 1-2 weeks. - Key side effects: Minimal; monitor for allergy or irritation. - Alternative medications: None typically needed unless symptoms worsen.  STEP 4 - NON-PHARMACOLOGICAL INTERVENTIONS: - Primary non-drug interventions: Avoid rubbing the eye, protect the eye from further trauma, and rest. - Patient education priorities: Explain that the condition is benign, common after trauma, and typically resolves spontaneously. - Lifestyle modifications: No specific changes required; advise moderation in strenuous activities if concerned about recurrence. - Behavioral interventions: Not applicable unless trauma-related activity needs to be avoided temporarily.  STEP 5 - MONITORING & FOLLOW-UP STRATEGY: - Follow-up timeline: Reassess in 1-2 weeks or sooner if symptoms worsen. - Monitoring parameters: Watch for increasing redness, pain, visual changes, or any signs of worsening injury. - Red flag symptoms: Severe pain, vision loss, persistent or increasing hemorrhage, or signs of globe rupture warrant immediate evaluation. - Treatment response assessment: Resolution of redness and swelling, no new symptoms.  STEP 6 - PATIENT COMMUNICATION STRATEGY: - Communication approach: Clearly explain that this is a common, benign condition that will resolve and that no aggressive medications are needed. - Addressing patient concerns: Reassure that no serious underlying disease is indicated unless symptoms change. - Adherence strategies: Encourage timely follow-up if symptoms persist or worsen; reinforce importance of avoiding eye trauma. - Family involvement: Not essential unless patient requests support, but informing family about signs needing urgent care can be helpful.  STEP 7 - COORDINATION & REFERRALS: - Specialist referrals needed: Not typically required unless complications or signs of other ocular trauma arise. - Other healthcare team members: Advise patient to see primary care provider if systemic symptoms occur or for routine follow-up. - Community resources: Provide eye safety education if injury was sports-related. - Insurance/cost considerations: Basic reassurance and minimal medication costs; ensure follow-up appointments are accessible.
